projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit, featuring 500 encoded political cartoons, that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program.

note.p: Abraham Lincoln served as president of the United States from 1861 until his assassination in 1865. He married Mary Todd Lincoln in 1842.

William Still was born in Burlington County, New Jersey, near Medford. His parents were both former slaves who escaped from their masters before William was born. Much of his childhood and young adult life was spent as a farmhand in New Jersey before he moved to Philadelphia in 1844. There he took on odd jobs until he finally established himself as a clerk for the Pennsylvania Anti-Slavery Society in 1847.

Also in 1847, William married Letitia George and they had four children. Letitia was a dressmaker who, for additional income, took boarders into the Still home in Philadelphia. She was a strong supporter of her husband's anti-slavery work and eventually witnessed and oversaw the transformation of her household from a home and boarding house into a frequent stop for fugitive slaves on the Underground Railroad in Philadelphia. The famous Henry "Box" Brown, for example, spent two nights in the Still home. By the latter half of the nineteenth century, however, Letitia's primary occupation concerned the business of running her household as the need to provide shelter for escaped slaves waned and the Still family was, by then, wealthy (one writer indicates that Still's "personal fortune was nearly $1 million" at the time of his death in 1902). The Still children likewise benefited from the family's financial security and their parents' ambition and dedication to social causes. Caroline Still, the eldest of the Still children, attended Oberlin College in Ohio and went on to become one of the first African American female physicians in Pennsylvania. She was an advocate for temperance, education, and the improvement of the conditions of the poor among other causes.

Though William Still himself was mostly self-educated, he excelled as a clerk at the Pennsylvania Anti-Slavery Society, was eventually appointed secretary and chairman of the Vigilance Committee in 1852, and kept meticulous records of that committee's efforts throughout the 1850s. His book, The Underground Rail Road, published in 1872, and his "Journal C" (which included records of the committee's finances), are the definitive sources regarding the Vigilance Committee's efforts. During his time working with the Pennsylvania Anti-Slavery Society, William was reunited with his brother, Peter, who had been kidnapped and sold into slavery forty years before the brothers' reunion. William Still's work, then, connected him with his own family, thousands of fugitive slaves, abolitionists, and many of the most prominent figures in Philadelphia, and, indeed, the United States.

Despite his ambitious work on the Underground Railroad and for the Vigilance Committee, Still took on additional causes and occupations beyond abolition. He protested against racial discrimination in Philadelphia's railroad cars, organized a Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA) for young blacks, and served on the Freedman's Aid Commission which offered assistance to newly-freed African Americans after the U.S. Civil War. After ending his employment with the Pennsylvania Anti-Slavery Society in 1861, Still also sold stoves and coal in Philadelphia and was, by his later years and until his death in 1902, a successful businessman.
